title: gangsters hiding uk fugitive behind
story: Exclusive: Gangsters hiding UK fugitive behind dad and sons Costa Del Sol disappearance - detectivePeter Bleksley believes Kevin Parle is being shielded by British drug traffickers in Spain, where car mechanic Danny Poole went missing along with his -year-old son Liam in April An articially aged image of what authorities think fugitive Kevin Parle, , might look like today Image: SWNS.COMByTom PettorCrime EditorRobin Eveleigh:,  Apr Gangsters suspected of harbouring one Britain’s most wanted fugitives could be behind the disappearance of a father and son on the Costa del Sol, a former detective believes.Peter Bleksley - who was the star of Channel  reality show ‘Hunted’ - has been on the trail of six-and-a-half foot Liverpudlian Kevin Parle since .Peter says Parle is being shielded by British drug traffickers in Spain, where car mechanic Danny Poole went missing along with his -year-old son Liam in April .Peter, who is chronicling his investigation in the hit BBC podcast ‘Manhunt - Finding Kevin Parle’, said: “I’ve now got a clear picture of how Kevin Parle remains on the run - what he does, who he does it for, and roughly where. “There’s a clear linkage between the network of criminals that have been harbouring and funding him, and the disappearance of Danny and Liam Poole. “It’s worthy of further investigation - the police need to take this very seriously.” The latest season of Manhunt, out on Tuesday, finds Peter on the trail of Parle in Almeria, south eastern Spain, where he believes his quarry has worked as hired muscle for an international drug trafficking ring. Peter reveals how an informant has told him the gangsters are behind the suspected murders of Danny and Liam.He said: “The source said they weren’t implicating Parle directly, but told me that ‘the father and son from Burgess Hill won’t be seen again.’ “I later met my source face-to-face and discussed Danny and Liam. The source told me the criminal network surrounding Kevin Parle was responsible for their disappearance. “I’ve also identied a number of iniduals in Parle’s network, some of whom have residential and business addresses on the south coast and Sussex, not far from where Danny and Liam were living. Everything points to these two cases being linked.” Danny, , and Liam, from Burgess Hill, Sussex, traveled to Spain’s Estepona on Mother’s Day  carrying a suitcase containing £, in cash.  Relatives last heard from them the following day - April . The cash was never recovered and their passports and luggage were found abandoned in a hotel room on Estepona’s Valle Romano golf resort. Liam’s mum Lisa Berwick says her former husband had links with the drug world, and believes he and their son were killed in a deal gone wrong. Peter reveals his bombshell findings to Lisa and daughter Lauryn Poole - Liam’s sister - in the podcast.  Lisa said: “I was shocked to hear Peter’s information - it seems journalists have done more to investigate Danny and Liam’s disappearance than the police. “It looks totally credible and should have blown the case wide open - yet it appears the police have just sat on it.” Lauryn fights back tears as she tells Peter: “Dad and Liam have very easily been portrayed as criminals. It’s important people realise they’re not just that - they’re two people we love. We need closure.” Parle - nicknamed ‘Hemp’ - is wanted for the shotgun murders of a mum-of-three Lucy Hargreaves and Liam Kelly, . He is one of  criminals who appear on the National Crime Agency’s ‘most wanted’ list.The -year-old has spent  years on the run from British authorities. Liam was gunned down over a £ debt in  as he climbed out of a pal’s Vauxhall Astra in Toxteth, Liverpool.In August , Lucy Hargreaves, , was shot three times by masked gunmen as she slept on her sofa in Walton, Merseyside, before being doused in petrol and set on fire.Lucy’s partner Gary Campbell - thought to be the intended target of the underworld hit - fled through an upstairs window with their toddler as their home blazed. Ginger-haired Parle is believed to have fled to Spain and is wanted for questioning on both murders.It is believed Danny and Liam met two British men - one with connections to Merseyside - in Estepona the night before they vanished. Spanish police confirmed they arrested the two men in June , but the pair were never charged. One subsequently ed to the UK and is currently serving an eight-year sentence for aggravated burglary. The other has been linked to another high-profile, unsolved disappearance in Spain where he still lives today. Although the pair took £k in cash on their trip, Lisa revealed Liam asked her to send more money the day after the pair arrived in Spain.  “I told him that I didn’t have that kind of money, and in any case I didn’t want the paper trail coming back to me. “Of course I can’t say for certain what happened from there, but I can imagine a scenario where Liam was held for ransom until Danny came up with the cash - and somehow it’s all gone wrong.”Lisa has criticised the Spanish authorities and Sussex Police over their handling of her son’s disappearance.Sussex Police say they are powerless to investigate in Spain. And the Superior Court of Andalucia closed the case in September  – a mere five months after Danny and Liam went missing.Peter handed his dossier linking Parle with Danny and Liam to Merseyside Police in December .But it is unclear whether the information has been acted upon. Merseyside Police refused to confirm what information was passed on - or when - saying only it had been “processed and disseminated accordingly.” Sussex Police said: “I can confirm that we have no evidence to link Kevin Parle with the disappearance of Danny and Liam Poole. “This is and always has been a Spanish judicial-led investigation and the role of Sussex police has been to support that with UK-based enquiries and liaison with the family.” Peter said: “If there are criminals out there making people disappear, then it is absolutely imperative that they are found and brought to justice - becausethey’ve done it before, they might do it again. “Every single resource possible should be ploughed into establishing the truth.” Last Sunday, on the eve of the third anniversary of the disappearances, Lisa spent another Mother’s Day without a visit from her son. “It reduced me to tears - again,” she said. “They say it gets easier with time but it doesn’t, it gets harder.” Read MoreRead More Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Liam KellyBBCMerseyside PoliceSussex PoliceChannel Crime" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Hundreds of biscuits packets strewn across road after spilling from McVities lorryThe biscuits were strewn across the road in Sandiacre, in Derbyshire, at about pm this evening as they tumbled out of the dozens of boxes packed on the lorryA lorry has spilt hundreds of McVitie’s biscuits in Sandiacre Image: Erewash Response WSByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Apr |commentsA lorry carrying a large delivery of McVitie’s biscuits spilt on the road this evening - sending packets of biscuits everywhere. The biscuits were strewn across the road as they tumbled out of the dozens of boxes packed on the lorry. The bizarre incident happened in Sandiacre in Derbyshire at about pm this evening. An Erewash police officer said: “Please bear with us this evening whilst we try and ‘digest’ this issue. A lorry load of McVitie’s finest have decided to abandon ship causing a slight obstruction!Traffic-monitoring service Inrix reported that the incident was affecting Ilkeston Road in Sandiacre in both directions, between Stanton Gate and Starch Lane, DerbyshireLive reports. Images from the scene showed hundreds of red plastic packages scattered over the road and the pavement.It comes after hundreds of stuffed animals were left strewn across a motorway last week, causing delays to drivers and drawing comparisons to Toy Story.The mystery spillage, which saw around  cuddly toys, including a Winne the Pooh bear, a Minion and several My Little Ponies, left transport officials in Oregon, US, scratching their heads. The blockage occurred around .am last Wednesday, resulting in a back up of vehicles on the interstate near the Burnside Bridge. Oregon Department of Transportation compared the incident to the Disney Pixar film series, joking the toys may have been on their way to Pizza Planet. Don Hamilton, DOT spokesperson, said one lane was closed to the cartoon creatures but said most of them were already to the side of the road. “It’s not often we get several hundred stuffed animals visiting our highways,” he added. It was not immediately clear where the toys came from. Hamilton claried they had, however, been taken to the North Portland maintenance yard for care and feeding. story: Incredible family has SEVEN children in dferent years at the same schoolOne member of the Shelley and Grange family dominates the school register at St Paul’s in Stalybridge, Greater Manchester and not to mention the previous generations that have already attendedFrom the left: Rose Shelley, Bobby Shelley, Frankie Grange, Stanley Shelley, Elise Shelley, Lilly Grange and Lily ShelleyByStephen WhiteNews Reporter:,  Apr |commentsA primary school really can call itself a family affair as it has one child from the same clan in each of its seven years. Not to mention the older children, parents, grandparents and great-grandparents who all attended previously. At the moment, one member of the Shelley and Grange family dominates the school register at St Paul’s in Stalybridge, Greater Manchester. And there are occasions where all seven turn up at once when they are with childminder Lisa Shelley, who also went to the school! Proud Shirley Shelley said: “There’s Lily Shelley, who turned -years-old on March . Then Lilly Grange, my daughter’s children, Elise Shelley, Stanley Shelley, Frankie Grange, Bobby Shelley and Rose Shelley.  “Three of their parents – Lisa, Bryn and Lee Shelley - went to St Paul’s, their granddad went too and their dad, Don, who’s -years-old, went there too! “On top of the ones who are there now, there’s Charlie and Oscar, who are  and , who went there. My daughter has Evie, who’s , who was at St Paul’s. “Whenever it comes up that someone has to pick which school a child goes to, they’re going to St Paul’s. It’s remarkable.  “I’ve asked the children and they all know they’re cousins, primarily because they look alike. “So I spoke to the headteacher and the Rev Emma Handley, who loves the fact they were all christened at her church. She says, ‘The Shelleys are here!’ “On Tuesdays and Thursdays, they all turn up to school together as they’re with my daughter-in-law Lisa, who’s a childminder and has the same name as my daughter, and she drops them off. “The school’s been a really important part of family le, also because of its links with the church and at the moment, this is the last year it will happen when all the kids will be in dferent years. “Butthe school’s still open, I think future generations may go there too...it’s a lovely church school.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON EducationSchools" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Manchester Airport worker says hes quit his job in disgust over way its runRay Ellis described Manchester Airports operations as chaotic and has concerns about passengers safety among the y queues and chaos at the hubRay Ellis has quit his job at Manchester Airport Image: manchestereveningnewsByPaul BrittonGraeme Murray:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsAn airport worker has quit his role in aposdisgustapos at the way at how a major transport hub is being operated. Ray Ellis described Manchester Airportaposs operations as chaoticapos and has concerns about passengers.The hub has left passengers facing long delays and been hit by staff shortagesTravellers have struggled to get through security and faced y queues as the Easter holiday season approaches Baggage handlers are also facing more stress and some passengers have abandoned luggage to get away after long waitAirport chiefs have warned queues could persist as the start of busy summer schedules and international travel slowly begins toto normal levels Mr Ellis, a father-of-three and grandfather from Wythenshawe, Manchester said the airport, which is battling to attract jobs and has launched a recruitment drive, should reduce flights until the situation eases.He told the Manchester Evening News: I am health and safety through and through.I am very well trained and used to be a health and safety rep at the airport as well as a trainer. I have worn many caps there and I know how things should be run. They are not being run in the way they should be. I am making this point and speaking out because I am genuinely concerned for passenger safety. Mr Ellis has also contacted Manchester City Council, which has shares in the airport, the mayor of Greater Manchesteraposs office, the Civil Aviation Authority and the Department for Transport. I am quite willing and able to give a tour of the airport to point out my concerns to anyone who would benefit from that, he added. It is the first job at the airport that I have walked out on. It is dreadful at the moment and getting dangerous.Among a series of allegations, Mr Ellis cited workers being offered a apos£ incentiveapos to forgo breaks during one sht amid claims passengers were forced to wait up to two hours to collect their luggage - he said the move was in breach of working time directives and compromised safety. The inconvenience that passengers are suffering is unjust. I would say that passenger safety is being endangered. The security is nowhere near what it should be at a major airport. While some owners turn to their friends and family for help, others seek inspiration from their favourite celebrities, music artists or television shows.On the back off the Peaky Blindersapos season finale, the name Shelby has appeared in the list of the nation’s top dog names for . The nationwide poll, conducted by the joint supplement brand for dogs,YuMOVE , found the hit TV show, starring Cillian Murphy, left a mark on the nation’s dog owners.The name Alfie swooped in at number three on the list of the top male dog names, again suggesting that Blinders-mad Brits have been inspired by Tom Hardy’s character, Jewish gang-leader, Alfie Solomans.to our TeamDogs newsletter for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories. The research was conducted in response to the recent  per cent spike in online searches for ‘adoption centres near me’ suggesting many Brits may be gearing up to welcome a new dog into their homes this spring. The male name Max stole the top spot for Brits, followed by Dave at number two – and it seems they’re not alone – sharing their preferences with some of the nation’s best loved celebrities and Hollywood superstars. Heidi Klum named her beautul German Shepherd, Max, who lives alongside her two other dogs, fellow Sheppy, Freddie and Irish Wolfhound, Anton, who she adopted on National Dog Day back in . And Gogglebox’s Malone family may well have bucked the trend after melting hearts with their Rottweiler, Dave.  Topping the list of female dog names were Bella, Daisy and Poppy.American actress and singer, Selena Gomez, revealed her gorgeous mixed-breed pooch, Daisy, on Instagram back in , after adopting her in lockdown last year.Charlie landed the top spot as the nation’s top unisex name – a sentiment echoed by actress Mischa Barton, who is regularly pictured out and about with her loveable spaniel, Charlie by her side.Coco also featured in the list, adopted by Ariana Grande for her Dachshund-German shepherd mix – the first of her  rescue dogs.  Jayne Laycock, resident vet at YuMOVE, said “S pring is a popular time of year to welcome a new dog into the home. Likewise, consider the age of the dog you’re looking to get – puppies require a lot of time, effort and training, soyou’re looking for something a little more ‘seasoned’ - then perhaps look at a rescue dog that’s a little older that’s already house trained. story: Prince Andrews trying to reinvent himself - but itll only work while Queens aliveWhy would a man so internationally humiliated try to force himself back into public le, wonders Fleet Street Fox Image: Getty ImagesopinionByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsHistorians of the future will devote books, doctorates, and entire symposiums to the question of what the hell goes on in Prince Andrewaposs mind.See a dodgy banker  Make friends, holiday, schmooze the girls that seem to always hang around, ignore the child abuse guilty plea, let your ex-we take a loan, then sweat for a decade before you decide to say sorry.See another dodgy banker  Take the money, be schmoozed, ignore questions about his bank going bust, let your ex-we take another loan, let your daughters take cash gts, pay back a bit, and say nothing.The Duke of York is nothingnot consistent. His only real problem is that he is consistent at making bad choices, and perhaps in time the worst of all will be when he decidednotto relinquish his motheraposs hand at the Westminster Abbey memorial for his father, to let her be led to her seat by someone  as he quietly slipped into his own.Instead Andrew kept her hand, eyeballed the Dean of Westminster into backing down, and flaunted the Head of the Church of England in front of a bank of TV cameras in the full knowledge that his fatheraposs memorial would be reduced to a news item re-upping allegations of sexual abuse.Worse than the public criticism, though, was the well-briefed fury of Charles and William, the next two monarchs who will not be as forgiving as the current one. And then the entirely-coincidental revelation that Andrew had not mended his ways, and had become embroiled with another scandal.This time itaposs a court case in which he, his ex-we and both his daughters are alleged to have been the beneficiaries of a grand swindle. A Turkish banker allegedly persuaded a Turkish millionairess to trust her cash to him, and she has told the court that he used the money to buy influence for himself with the Royals.The Turkish banker was applauded at the princeaposs now-defunct Pitch@Palace initiative, and around the same time Andrew received £.m, his ex-we £,, and his daughter Eugenie a further £,.The millionairess says she was told the money was for a passport. Coutts says they were told it was to pay for Beatriceaposs wedding. This is despite the fact a passport costs £., and Beatrice married a millionaire.  Andrew has now repaid the £,, but a further £, is unaccounted for. The Duchess of York has refused toher chunk, on the grounds it was paid for her work as a brand ambassador for a green energy company, even though it does not seem to be benefitting much from the connection. Beatriceaposs friends have described her as completely unaware of how her wedding was paid for, while Eugenie has let it be known she spent the £, on a surprise birthday party for her mother.And the question must now be asked of the entire family: what is it about dodgy money that attracts you Becausea £, bill for a wedding was settled by a Turkish political exile, any other bride would know about it. If any other woman got six-figure sums from her ex-husbandaposs chums she might wonder why. Andany one of us wanted to throw a surprise party and found it cost the same as a new car, weaposd throw a smaller onewe didnapost have the means to pay for it. Now the Royal Family finds itself in the unenviable situation of having paid £.million between them to make a scandal go away, just as the Duke of York manages to drive them smack into a new one - one which makes them look entitled, opportunistic, and desperate for cash to supplement a lestyle they cannot afford.At a time when the rest of the nation knows to the nearest penny what they can afford, and are turning off the heating or adjusting their shopping habits to scrape by, the fact that the future Royal Family canapost imagine a wedding that costs less than three quarters of a million pounds is not going to improve its long-term chances of survival.The timing of this court case, which has rumbled on for a couple of years, suddenly being made public in the week after Andrew embarrassed his relatives is interesting. And it may be linked to the fact that the Duke, who just a few months ago confirmed his public appearance at the memorial would be the last, is now reportedly considering smearing his pudgy chops across the Derby, a Falklands anniversary event, and the Platinum Jubilee. Why would a man who vowed to step away from the spotlight now be so intent on hogging it  Read more Prince Andrew is a true pauper prince - a man of poor wit, poor talent, and poor judgement. All that makes him rich is his title, and after giving up every other honoric his HRH is the one thing he has held onto. He is not allowed to use it, but he does still have it.He also held on to his daughtersapos titles, when other siblings relinquished them in favour of a more normal le. He fought for his daughtersapos Royal security, when it was costing £m a year and creating bad news as Met police officers were forced to trail after two girls on their gap yahs. For all the criticism levelled at Harry and Meghan for trying to trade off their Royal titles, Andrew and Sarah of York have done exactly that for decades, and with far more disastrous consequences. It perhaps explains why sheaposs still Sarah of York. Whoaposd want to change their name,it would cost you the chance to earn £, without having to go down the pit  Having lost his reputation, his ski chalet, millions of pounds and the trust of most of his wider family, Andrew seems to be intent on reinventing himself - not as a changed or chastened man, but as a prince, who needs to show no humility or shame. With the Queen by his side, Andrew can try it. But he has underestimated two things. The first is the fury of the British public, which does not forgive sexual misconduct in public le that easily, still less so when it involves someone legally a child. And the second is the ruthlessness of monarchy - the one quality which has been passed through that family since William the Conqueror. Charles may go easy on his younger brother, but William seems to feel nothing but scorn for playboy princes with dubious means of financial support. There will not be space on William Vaposs balcony for Uncle Andrew, nor much patience with the York familyaposs inability to adjust their lestyle to suit their income. Andrew is therefore working against the clock -being a prince is what turns a buck, then how much of a prince can he be, in the time his mother has left  The answer must be: for as long as her family lets the Queen be so exploited.Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Sarah FergusonPrince Philip, Duke of EdinburghPrince Andrew, Duke of YorkRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: residents call ban school run
story: Residents call for ban on school run parking as cars cause mayhem in streetResidents near Hotspur Primary School in Heaton, Newcastle, are fuming as parents dropping off their children are double parking outside their homesResidents of Mowbray Street in Heaton, Newcastle, want school run parents to be banned from double parking outside their homes Image: North News  Pictures Ltd northnewsByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |comments Angry residents have called for a council to ban school -run parents from blocking their road to drop off kids. Heavily pregnant Mariama Diallo says double parking outside Hotspur Primary School in Heaton, Newcastle, is putting pupilsapos lives at risk and needs to be stopped.The mum-of-three, , said sheaposs petried of allowing her daughters, Kadiatou, eight, and Aissatou, seven, to go to school on their own despite only living opposite it. Mowbray Street - where parking is only permitted on one side - often gets crammed full of cars. Mariama, ideally, would like to be able to watch from her door to check her children are safely at school - due to her condition making moving around dficult. But she said the current situation makes that too dangerous and sheaposs worried due to the sheer amount of cars moving in and out.Is there a similar issue on your street  Let us know at webnews@mirrorShe told the Sun: I am scared they will hit the children.Referring to the call for cars to be banned, she added it will be annoying but safety has to come first and is more important. Fellow resident, Francis Hamilton, , said the situation is horrible and when he drops his grandson at nursery he often canapost get a parking space at all. He said between .am and .am he canapost park or get his car out.  Parents park wherever they want to. They are double-parked from the bottom all the way up, he explained. While he is open to the idea of the council banning parents parking near his home he said it would exacerbate the issue as the problem could move to other streets. Linda Cherry, , said the local authority needs to introduce parking permits and install cameras to gather the culpritsapos registration numbers. She added that the back lanes near the school are also clogged up, while at all times of day people park in the area to go shopping in the town centre. She said she often drives around for  minutes trying to get parked up when ing home. Linda said as well as the children she is worried about her pet cats getting hurt. A spokesperson for Newcastle City Council said: “Since announcing our intention to put in place School Streets last year we have been working directly with the schools we’d identied as a first phase in the programme. One of the most important things in the delivery of this programme is to work with people who might be affected and listen to their concerns so we can address them. “One of our team has been visiting the schools regularly and working with the teachers, young people and those who live nearby to help understand the impacts and how we can promote and manage School Streets, or indeed where they might not be the right solution at this point in time. We’ve also undertaken trial runs of School Streets at a number of locations. “We had been waiting for government to formally transfer certain enforcement powers to local authorities, and to provide funding for measures of this type, something we’re happy to note has now been brought forward.Many schools have told us they would like to see these powers in place alongside implementing schemes to help ensure pupil’s safety. “Pupils at Hotspur Primary School are currently leading the way as part of our Big Walk and Wheel competition, with nearly two thirds of trips being active. “This is a competition we’re running with schools who’ve opted in across the city and it complements ongoing work we’re doing with the city’s Promise Board, which represents every single schools trust across the city, to bring forward a joint approach to improving safety and sustainability for the school run.” The Mirror has contacted Hotspur Primary School for comment. recent Caribbean tour was on the receiving end of some backlash after a series of PR blunders. story: Woman who moved to UK with kids dies on holiday after being set on fire by husbandMum-of-four Chinyere Ogudoro died after being set on fire by her husband in Lagos, Nigeria. Her husband Benjamin Ogudoro, has been arrested on suspicion of murderChinyere Ogudoro moved to Scotland four years ago to studyBySamantha Mordi:,  Apr  A mum-of-four has died after being allegedly set on fire by her estranged husband, leaving her heartbroken friends and family wondering why her.Chinyere Ogudoro, , and her brother Ifeanyi Edoziem both suffered fatal injuries during an incident at her family home in Lagos, Nigeria. Sadly, Ms Ogudoro who has been described by friends as a data enthusiast died instantly, while her brother managed to escape, before dying in hospital. Her husband Benjamin Ogudoro, , has been arrested on suspicion of murder and is said to have set his we and brother-in-law on fire as they slept. In the statement, reported by Nigerian newspaper The Nation, he said: I went to pick my sister from the Murtala Muhammed International Airport when she ed.  We were sleeping when her husband came in late, banging on the door. We had a little misunderstanding as he accused me of locking him outside. I told him I didnapost bolt the door that I only used the key lock, and besides, he could have opened it since he had his keys with him. He kept shouting that I locked him out. He insulted me and my sister but we kept quiet. He left the room only towhen we had fallen asleep. He poured petrol on us, lit a match and went out. We were burning. I managed to escape but couldnapost save my sister. Mrs Ogudoro moved to Scotland four years ago to study at Glasgow Caledonian University and gained a masteraposs degree in international business management. She travelled home to Nigeria on Thursday and died at the scene of the incident in the early hours of Friday morning.  Her younger brother died later in hospital but was able to give a dying declaration to police alleging that his brother-in-law was responsible. Reports in Nigeria say Mrs Ogudoro had ed to speak with her husband after finding out he planned to sell their family home without her permission. Her children are believed to still be in Scotland.Speaking to the BBC, Edna Durueke, a -year-old aunt of the victims, said Mr Ogudoro had originally joined his family in Scotland before ing home.She said: My niece got a student visa to travel to Scotland. The visa allowed her to take her family so she took her four children and her husband.  Nobody knows what happened to make the husband decide toto Nigeria. No one heard my relatives shouting in the house. Describing the incident, she said: Around am neighbours realised what happened as they started to smell smoke. No one heard my relatives shouting in the house. Mrs Ogudoro had set up home in Glasgow and set up her own management consultancy company in the city after graduating from university. Friends have paid tribute to Mrs Ogudoro, who worked in banking in Nigeria before moving to Scotland, on social media. Chime Chimezie-uche wrote: Itaposs still a shock that you are gone. You cared so much for your children. Your death is painful Chinyere. Rest in Peace. Odunayo Ogunsanwo posted: Spoke with her two days before she went to Nigeria. She was a data enthusiast that did all to learn more and earn a new legacy. Why Chinyere Ogudoro of all people  Dr Colin Combe, of the Department of Business Management at Glasgow Caledonian University, said: I am very shocked and saddened to hear of the tragic death of Chinyere. I was able to get to know Chinyere well and admired her dedication to her studies and the welfare of her children and wider family. Her motivation for undertaking the course was to enable a better future for them. Chinyere will be missed by all who knew her and I send my heartfelt condolences to her family and friends. story: Loyal dog waits by owners side for two weeks after he dies suddenly while hikingKing, the loyal dog of Oscar Henandez, stayed by his owners side for two weeks as he lay dead in a Los Angeles park. The dog was hungry but healthy when foundHiker Oscar Alejandro Hernandez was found dead with his dog by his sideByHilary HansonSamantha Mordi:,  Apr |commentsA hiker who went missing for two weeks was tragically found dead - with his loyal dog by sitting by his side.Oscar Alejandro Hernandez body was found near a Los Angeles park on Thursday.The -year-oldaposs dog, King was found next to him hungry, but alive. His family raised alarm bells in mid-March, issuing a flyer which said his last known location was a merry-go-round near the Grfith par location. Hernandez’s family was present when his body was found, Los Angeles Sgt. Ruben Arellano. The man’s cousin said he believes King never left Hernandez’s side. Multiple agencies worked to retrieve Hernandez’s body from the hilly area.  Authorities have not yet released a cause of death for Hernandez, but there’s no reason to suspect foul play, Arellano said. Grfith Park covers more than , acres and includes around  miles of hiking trails and grassy areas. This comes after a loyal dog sat on the spot where its homeless owner died on a bench outside a hospital. The moving scene took place outside Rio Piedras Medical Centre in the Puerto Rican capital San Juan on the morning of February .According to the news site El Universal, the -year-old homeless man passed away in the night and the dog stayed by his side. The loyal pooch even remained on the bench as personnel from the Institute of Forensic Sciencestook the body away, gazing at the morgue vehicle as it disappeared from view. However, medical staff took a liking to the dog, and Dr Jose Antonio Herrera Dalmau reportedly decided to adopt the ownerless animal.  He told the newspaper El Nuevo Dia: I have already made an appointment to see a vet because the dog has a leg injury. It is not broken, but it has an injury. The hospital doctor added that he was thinking of calling the pooch Leo. He said he was told about the dog by a colleague and went outside to take a look. The doctor, who says he is a dog lover, explained that Leo looks a lot like a pet pooch he had several years ago called Reina. The canine colourist spends up to £, a year on premium colours for her three-year-old poodle and claims that each makeover can take her up ten hours at a time. After each unique transformation, Walter looks completely unrecognisable as he sports bright blue, green and even checkerboard print fur. Each masterpiece involves a lot of planning as Jessica, who is now a full-time creative dog groomer, meticulously trims, colours and blow-dries her trusty service dog.Jessica said: Iaposve always had a passion for film. I used to work in the film industry, however I had to take some time off because I was getting sick. When it was lockdown and there was nothing to do, I started going crazy in the house looking to do something creative so I started practicing looks on Walter. After a year of having him, I started doing the crazy looks on him whenever I was having a dficult time as this really helped me.Iaposve had Walter since he was a puppy and he is trained to help me for when I have vertigo and migraine episodes.As well as being a great model, he really helps me because heaposs trained in de-pressure therapy. When Iaposm feeling light-headed, he lies on my body and really helps me control my breathing.Whilst Walteraposs looks turn heads in the street when heaposs out for walks, the creative groomer says that a lot of planning and effort goes into the looks and her doggy makeover addiction costs her a fortune. She adds: Luckily, I have a really well behaved dog and heaposs happy to sit there the whole time. Over the past two years, Iaposve spent around £, on colours which last up to  washes. When I do the slinky dog look, it took me up around  hours because I had to carve out where I would shave and it was really dficult to get the tail shaped right.After each crazy look, I shave him right down to the skin but heaposs a poodle so this grows back fully in about four months ready for the next look. At first, I was worried what people would think but when people see us on the street, they stop me to tell me how beautul he looks - some have even stopped traffic to tell me he looks amazing. Everything I use is vegan and cruelty-free, the colour is actually so safe a human could probably ingest it. Iaposve now undergone my own training and Iaposve started working in a shop, however I donapost recommend people trying this on their own dogthey donapost know what theyaposre doing. story: Real-le Rapunzel goes viral after cutting her ft-long hair for first time in  yearsA woman likened to a real-le rapunzel has gone viral after cutting her ft-long her into a chin- bob - and wants to inspire other women to make bold and brave decisionsVanessa Rasmusson, , after she cut her calf- ft hair to a chin- bob Image: @vanessa.r News Dog MediaByPesala BandaraCharlie Duffield:,  Apr |commentsA woman likened to a real-le rapunzel has gone viral after cutting her ft-long her into a chin- bob.Mum-of-two Vanessa Rasmusson, , from Utah, USA, became famous on TikTok @vanessa .r for her calf- hair, which hadnapost been trimmed for  years.Yet recently, she made the decision to cut it, after realising how her own self-worth was dependent on her having long hair. When she was seven years old, Vanessa had her hair cut short. She hated how it looked, and pledged never to cut her hair again. As her locks grew longer and longer, she became used to compliments and accrued an online following for her Rapunzel-like hairstyle.Vanessa – who has a daughter Rose,  and son, Jasper,  with her husband,  – told News Dog Media : “When I was seven, I got my hair cut and hated it and promised myself that I would never cut it short again. “I loved having long hair and I was curious to see how long it would grow. I never expected that my hair would grow to my calves! “But it just kept growing. In fact, I saw the most growth in my hair when I had my two kids. “People began to compliment me on my long hair all the time. But after doing a lot of soul-searching, I realised it was no longer serving me and it was actually causing me more resistance in my le. “I was becoming a dferent person to who I used to be when I was seven years old.“I wanted to try something dferent and let go of that identity. Part of that transformation meant letting go of hair. “My four-foot long hair had always made me stand out. But I no longer wanted to be viewed just for my hair, I wanted to be viewed as a person.” In November last year, Vanessa secretly went to the hairdresser. She revealed her hair transformation to the world when she shocked her , TikTok followers with her short bob. She explains: “I only told a handful of people including my husband before I cut my hair. “I didn’t want anyone’s opinion to affect my decision. I wanted to cut my hair for me. “I was excited but nervous about getting the chop. I was shocked when I first saw it gone but I was also surprised that I felt pretty and confident with short hair too. “Also I had never realised the sheer weight of my long hair on my neck for all those years. It was so light now.Vanessa unveiled her dramatic haircut on TikTok with trepidation, and was worried that she would lose social media followers. But whilst trolls attacked her haircut, she also gained followers who were impressed by her bold decision. Now she wants to inspire other women to make liberating changes in their le as well. Vanessa says: “I was scared people would unfollow me when I cut my hair. Butanything, that solidied my decision to go to the hairdresser. I had to face my fear that some people only cared about my hair. “When I revealed my transformation on TikTok, of course there were people who told me I wasn’t special or unique anymore without my long hair. Some users threatened to unfollow me, whilst others tried to console me by telling me my hair would grow back. “But I actually got way more follows from my haircut video because it was so extreme. It was quite cool to see that!“Cutting my hair made me face lots of beliefs I had about myself. It made me see the beauty in myself – beyond my hair. “It made me realise my worth doesn’t change according to what I wear or how I look. “I want to show women that their worth doesn’t depend on certain attributes either. You’re amazing because you’re you. “I hope my decision allows other people to examine themselves too and seethey are holding on to things that might be negative. Letting go brought me so much joy. “I’m really loving my short hair right now. story: Cleaning expert reveals why you should disinfect your lamps every weekA cleaning expert has urged people to remember the importance of keeping on top of bedroom hygiene, which includes remembering to disinfect objects you may well forget about, such as lamps" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _Senior-woman-sitting-in-bed-at-night-with-tablet.jpg" width"" "" Many people underestimate just how dirty bedside lamps can getImage: Getty ImagesByJulia BanimAudience Writer:,  Apr |commentsMany of us will know all too well the importance of keeping kitchens and bathrooms spick and span, but weaposll often neglect to remember the dirt and grime that can accumulate in the average bedroom.According to advice recently published by fitted bedroom supplier Online Bedrooms, muck can build up in the most unexpected of places, from pillows to curtains. Perhaps most surprisingly, the cosy bedroom lamp can become a hotbed of germsleft uncleaned, with bacteria building up quickly without the owner giving it so much as a second thought. According to this guidance, lampshades and map bases offer plenty of room for dust and dirt to settle and build, with lamps also known to be common touchpoints. This means a bit of dusting wonapost sufficewant to get them fully clean.Indeed, Online Bedrooms experts advise people to disinfect their lamps every week to keep filth at bay. Another secret offender is your seemingly clean bedroom curtains, which will gather dust, dog or cat hair, and even mould spores as time goes on.Each time you open the curtains, particles of dirt end up swirling around the air. Therefore, itaposs recommended that curtains should be washed at least twice a year, and more frequently still should you suffer from dust allergies. Although there are few things more comforting than laying your head on your softest pillow at night, pillows can actually accumulate more than several thousand times more bacteria than a toilet seat in the space of a week. Organisms found on pillowcases thankfully tend to be mostly harmless, consisting largely of a build-up of skin cells, sweat, and saliva, but itaposs recommended that you wash your bedding every week to keep things as fresh as possible. With this in mind, people are also urged to change their mattress every seven to eight years, with yeast, mould, and bacteria known to make themselves just as comfy in your bed as you do. Microbes, skin cells, and particles of food are all transferred from our bodies to our mattresses, while airborne particles of dust and debris end up settling on the bed after floating around the room. Nic Shacklock, from Online Bedrooms, said: “It is no secret that germs live all over our houses, however there are lots of hidden spots that we may not ever think about during our cleaning rituals. “Spots like pillowcases and curtains are silent killers. story: I erased my maid of honours tattoos from our wedding photos - now shes furiousA new bride decided that her maid of honours tattoos were not in keeping with her regency-era-themed wedding and so decided to Photoshop them out. As she and her new husband are both historians - who met through their research of the Regency era - they wanted their wedding to look just like something out of Bridgerton, as a way to honour our beginnings. When it came to her maid of honour, the -year-old bride decided on her childhood friend Jessica, who happens to have tattoos on her hands, legs, torso, and neck.When she asked Jessica what she intended to do about the tattoos on the big day so as to be in keeping with the traditional look, Jessica replied that, although she understood how important the theme was to the couple, she wasnapost going to be covering up her body art. Although the bride admits she was a little mfed by this reluctance, she didnapost push things any further and wanted to respect Jessicaaposs boundaries. She also wasnapost too worried, as the bridesmaids would be wearing gloves, meaning only her neck tattoos would be visible. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. However, on the day itself, Jessica turned up wearing short gloves rather than the long ones the bride had expected, meaning her arm tattoos were on full display. Sheaposd also had her neckline unexpectedly adjusted at the last minute, taking her by surpriseTaking to Reddit, she recalled: I did not expect this and was kind of thrown off, but after a while, I stopped caring and was busy having the best day of my le.However fast forward to a few weeks ago, I got back the first set of pictures from my wedding day and the pics with Jessica in them were jarring, to say the least, because of her tattoos. Jessica was very very mad when she saw the pic and told me this was a narcissistic and disrespectful thing to do and stormed out of my house, she was madder than I ever expected her to be so now I’m not sureI was truly way out of line, or just a little bit selfish. Giving further clarication, the poster explained that she believes Jessicaaposs tattoos to be beautul and uniquely her, but simply felt they didnapost fit in with the theme of the ceremony. Another said: You were wearing period costumes that you paid for and she modied herswithout your consent. The bride and groom are supposed to be the focus of attention at their own wedding, but she dominated the pictures because she insisted on displaying tattoos. transform an old wooden cabinet in a few simple steps, saving herself hundreds of pounds by doing so.Amanda Vernaci, from Michigan, US, wanted to enhance her space while keeping to a budget and headed to Facebook Marketplace in search of inspiration.It was here that the -year-old content creator came across a glass-fronted wooden cabinet, for the bargain price of  , and decided to treat herself.Given that the cabinet was looking a little scuffed and worse for wear, Amanda decided to harness her impressive DIY skills to transform her thrty new purchase into a piece of furniture anyone would be proud to own.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Amanda said: “I found this cabinet and had a space in my living room that was in need of a cabinet. When I found this piece, I knew I could turn it into something beautul. “First, I took off all the hardware, nails, screws, and glass, before cleaning the whole piece from top to bottom. I decided to close the sides of the cabinet and keep the glass on the doors. “I used a thin backer board to fill in the space left by the glass and enclose the cabinet sides. Next, I filled in the holes and caulked all the seams, before I prepped the cabinet for paint. She continued: “I sanded the inside, as well as the outside, and then used ‘Grizzle Gray’ by Sherwin Williams to paint the whole cabinet. “I used a paint sprayer to get a clean, even look and once the paint was dry, I installed the original hardware for the doors as I loved the character they added to the cabinet.Amanda, who lives with her husband TJ and one-year-old son AJ, built the shelves from thick plywood, as she needed to be able to support the weight of the items she wanted to display. She measured and chopped the plywood, and then added a pine board to the front so as to create a “cleaner” finish. According to Amanda: “This makes a more professional look, as plywood has a raw, unattractive edge and I also stained the shelves before installing [this.] “I created cleats along the back and sides to support the shelves and brackets with pine boards and used wood putty to fill in the holes.” Amanda spent £.on new glass  and £.on wood and other such materials, with custom-made glass added to the doors, which she had measured and had cut at a local glass shop, setting her back £. . title: vets plea owners putting dog
story: Vets plea to owners putting their dog to sleep after seeing their final momentsThe vet, who has seen countless dogs being put to sleep during their career, understands that its hard for owners to watch but says they should always trythey canThe vet is urging owners to stay with their pets in their final moments Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByPaige FreshwaterContent Editor:,  Apr |commentsSaying goodbye to a pet is devastating - but knowing theyaposre no longer in pain makes it easier to manage. While most owners struggle through their petaposs final moments, others choose to avoid it and wait in the hallway for it all to be over. Although it might be easier for you to sit it out, you might want to reconsider and put yourself through the pain of watching for their benefit.A vet has shared a heartbreaking message to owners who leave their pets alone when theyaposre being put to sleep - and is urging them to stay with them no matter how dficult it is. to our TeamDogs newsletter for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories. Speaking to Reddit, one vet said: It might be hard to say goodbye but it’s hell for them. They already don’t like the vet, they’re confused, they’re scared, they’re sad and they’re looking for you when they take their last breath. I can try to provide them as much love and comfort as I humanly can but at the end of the day, I’m a stranger to them. Explaining how a woman dropped off her -year-old dog to be euthanised, the vet said the poor pooch spent its final moments desperately scanning the room for her owner. She added: I told her we didn’t have a vet in clinic as she was on farm calls all day, but she insisted on leaving her there at am knowing that our vet wouldn’t be back until well after pm. She was too busy to bring her back later, so she left her sweet girl to be alone all day before dying.  I kept her with me for most of the day, took her for a small walk, bought her a cheeseburger and donut on my lunch and laid on the ground and cuddled her while she cried, scared and confused. I kissed her and told her she was a good girl while she crossed the rainbow bridge, but her eyes never stopped looking for her family. Dogs know what’s happening, don’t do this to them. Be there when they cross that bridge. It won’t kill you, I promise.Sharing their sympathies with those unable to stay with their pets as the injection is administered, the vet stressed: This very obviously does not apply to anyone who had absolutely no choice during the pandemic.While most users thanked the vet for their honestly, others recalled their own heartbreaking experiences with having to say goodbye to a beloved pet.One user said: While it is one of the hardest things we ever have to do, itaposs our last gt of love to them, after a letime of devotion. We stopped at McDonaldaposs and I ordered her a chocolate sundae. She had refused food for two days prior, but had a tentative, single lick of the chocolate while we cuddled her. My vet is one of the kindest people alive. He comes out to our car and gives her a big cuddle. He positions us so I can cuddle her and look into her eyes as she passes. He wants the last thing she sees to be me reassuring her. He checks her heart beat and steps away to let us have a private moment together, and I can hear him behind his own car having a quite cry to himself. He goes back in to treat his next patient, and when I am ready I go in to thank him. He cries again, I cry too. He gives me a hug and I head home with my lovely girl, to place her with her mates who went before her. Another added: I recently held my sweet little angel baby as her body went limp in my arms. A piece of me died that day but she was surrounded by love and died peacefully in my arms feeling safe. I cannot fathom not being there for her as she drew her last breaths. We truly don’t deserve the love, adoration and loyalty of dogs. A third said: I lost two dogs and a cat this year and my we and I rearrange our schedules to be with them as much as possible before they were put down and we were there during the procedures. It was horrible but we had them for  and  years so they were family. While I can understand not wanting to acknowledge that itaposs happening and wanting to pretend that they are just in the other room, trust me that itaposs better to be there for every second you can for closure and support. it to a professional hairdresser wasnapost the smart move she had assumed it would be - as her stylist managed to completely ruin her locks. story: Drag queen who cant stay home and watch Putin invade joins Ukrainian militaryArthur Ozerov started serving in the Ukrainian military a month ago, having forged a successful le for himself as a drag queen and bee keeper during peace timeArthur Ozerov in character as AuRa, the Ukrainian drag queen Image: aura_dragqueen InstagramByMilo BoydNews Reporter:,  Apr |comments A beekeeping drag queen from Ukraine has decided to join the military to fight off the Russian invaders. Arthur Ozerov has spent the past few years making a name for himself on the Kyiv drag circuit under the stage name AuRa. When not dressing up and wowing crowds, the -year-old was busy looking after his bee colony.As with many people in Ukraine, the Russian invasion at the end of February has required Arthur to turn his le in a dferent direction quite suddenly.Now on his social media s Arthur can be seen donning a camouflage unorm, having first signed up to the military at the beginning of March.  The openly gay man has taken a position in military administration with a focus on logistical coordination of local relief efforts.When asked why he stepped up and joined the battle against the Russian invaders, he told LGBTQ Nation : “I love my country. Therefore, I decided that I should make every effort to somehow help.“I can’t just sit home and watch how people are killed, houses are destroyed.” Arthur, who was married previously to a woman before realising something was missing, is out of the closet and supported by his friends. The role Arthur is performing in the military, and the clear pride he has for his country, may help to improve the reputation of LGTBQ people in a country with a complicated relationship with the community. As in Russia, gay marriage is banned in Ukraine, and attitudes about it are generally more conservative than in the UK.While gender and sexuality politics are not at the forefront of peopleaposs minds when hundreds of thousands of troops enter their country, they are clearly a key part of Vladimir Putinaposs propaganda war. In the past decade the Russian president has spoken forcefully for traditional values - a euphemism for nuclear, heterosexual families - and done much to undermine the safety and prosperity of those in the LGBTQ community. The  law banning “propaganda for non-traditional sexual relationships” among minors not only restricted opportunities speak and inform about sexuality and gender issues in public, but also designated homosexuality as a danger to children and to society. In  a ban on same-sex marriage was added to the Russian Constitution. The Kremlin has spun a narrative that LGBT rights are a weapon used by the West to weaken and destabilise Russia, the Boston Review reports. Speaking to students in Belarus in , Russia’s foreign minister Sergey Lavrov said Christian values needed to be protected from “same-sex values that are being imposed . . . coarsely and openly.” When the countryaposs tanks rolled into Ukraine on February , Putinaposs dramatic late-night speech was carefully drafted to touch on his hot button, culture war issues. Properly speaking, the attempts to use us in their own interests never ceased until quite recently: they sought to destroy our traditional values and force on us their  values that would erode us, our people from within, the attitudes they have been aggressively imposing on their countries, attitudes that are directly leading to degradation and degeneration, because they are contrary to human nature, he said.  This is not going to happen. No one has ever succeeded in doing this, nor will they succeed now. Patriarch Kirill, the leader of the Russian Orthodox Church, has been even more explicit about what he understands to be at stake in the war. For eight years there have been attempts to destroy what exists in Donbas, he said, referring to the long contested eastern Ukrainian state. Donbas has fundamentally refused to accept the so-called values that are being offered by those aspiring for worldwide power. There is a specic test of loyalty to these powers, a requirement for being permitted into the happy world of excessive consuming and apparent freedom. This test is very straightforward and at the same time horrying—the gay parade. The demand to organize a gay-parade is a test of loyalty to this powerful world. The implication when it comes to Ukraine is that the country is stuck in a tug-of-war between the liberal West and Russia, halfway between its liberal and conservative values. title: grieving family huddle mass grave
story: Grieving family huddle by mass grave in Ukraine as bodies continue to be foundUkraine President Volodymyr Zelensky accused Moscow of ­genocide after he toured the devastated town of Bucha, where  residents were found dead, some bound and gaggedMass graves, possible evidence of war crimes, have been found in Bucha Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByChris Hughes, Defence and Security Editor in the Carpathian Mountains, Ukraine:,  Apr |comments A grieving family huddle in tears by a mass grave in Ukraine, as calls grow for Vladimir Putin to face a war crimes trial over a string of ­civilian executions by his forces. An emotional Volodymyr Zelensky again accused Moscow of ­genocide after he toured the devastated town of Bucha, where  residents were found dead, some bound and gagged.The Ukrainian President claimed ­thousands of people have been murdered and butchered by rampaging Russian troops since they invaded the country. As more mass graves were discovered, Mr Zelensky said: “It will be recognised by the world as genocide. We know of ­thousands of people killed and tortured, with their limbs severed, women raped and children killed.”  Speaking about the massacre in Bucha, just outside the capital Kyiv, he added: “Hundreds of people were killed, tortured. Corpses on the street, mined areas. Even the bodies of the dead were mined. “Concentrated evil has come to our land. Murderers, torturers, rapists, looters who call ­themselves the army, and who deserve only death after what they did.” But shameless Moscow officials accused Ukrainians of staging the killings. Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov said: “From what we have seen, our experts have identied signs of video falsication and other fakes.” Mr Zelensky has set up a special body to ­investigate Russian war crimes – a call echoed by US President Joe Biden.He said: “I decided to create a special ­mechanism of justice in Ukraine to ­investigate and prosecute every crime of the occupiers in our country.” It will include “international experts, ­investigators, ­prosecutors and judges”. More than  corpses have been ­examined by forensic ­scientists preparing dossiers for future war crimes tribunals. Intelligence chiefs have a target list of Russian troops from  infantry brigades allegedly behind atrocities in Bucha.In Motyzhyn, to the west of Kyiv, the bodies of four people who appeared to have been shot at close range were seen in a pit. Boris Johnson branded the discovery “sickening”. Keir Starmer said Russian soldiers involved in war crimes in Ukraine should know “for the rest of their lives” they will be “chased down” and prosecuted. Foreign Secretary Liz Truss last night called for Russia to be kicked off the UN’s Human Rights Council over the ­atrocities. She said: “After these appalling crimes, Russia has no place on it.”As many as  schools daily have been hit by warplanes since the invasion started, Save The ­Children revealed. More than two million kids have fled while around . million remain. Up to , ­civilians are still unable to leave the besieged town of Mariupol. Grim ­statistics reveal  children have been killed and  injured.  Ukraine’s foreign minister Dmytro Kuleba said the port city had suffered an even worse onslaught than Bucha. He added: “The horrors we have seen in Bucha are just the tip of the iceberg of all the crimes that have been committed by the Russian army in Ukraine.” An evacuation convoy escorted by the International Committee of the Red Cross was blocked in the town of Manhush as it attempted to reach Mariupol last night. Kharkiv resident Olena Kolesnik, who fled to Poland, said: “This is genocide. This is fascism. Growing evidence points to barbarism in Bucha with local women and children raped and shot and demands are growing for accountability over atrocities by Vladimir Putinaposs forces. Ukrainian reporter Evgeny Spirin said: “Some of the killed children had their arms tied up. Children…. They were tying up children. There were shot dogs.  He added: “Irpen, Bucha, Dmitrievka. How to live with this, and is it worth living at all  How do I explain this to myself, how  “They must cease to exist. They must all be destroyed, each and every one of them, turned into dust, into mud, into clay, all of them.”Ukrainian activists and web sleuths have identied the presence of Omurbekov’s forces - which are normally based in the far east of Russia - and a number of other Russian military units. Volunteers group Tretya Sila reported: In Bucha there was a military unit  from the village of Knyaze-Volkonskoye, Khabarovsk region... “Soon all these murderers, rapists and looters will be known by name. InformNapalm volunteers named Omurbekov as unit  of the th Separate Motorized Rle Brigade amid suspicions of grotesque war crimes in Bucha. Russian ambassador to the US Anatoly Antonov said: “The Russian defence ministry has fully rejected these  accusations.” He said: ”I would like to point out that Russian troops left Bucha on March . “The Ukrainian authorities remained silent all these days, and now they have suddenly posted sensational footage in order to tarnish Russia’s image and make Russia defend itself. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. title: ruby house
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details.
